trans-unit.source: Create and upload a Windows Server VHD to Azure
trans-unit.target: Create and upload a Windows Server VHD to Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn to create and upload a virtual hard disk (VHD) in Azure that has the Windows Server operating system.
trans-unit.target: Learn to create and upload a virtual hard disk (VHD) in Azure that has the Windows Server operating system.

trans-unit.source: Create and upload a Windows Server VHD to Azure
trans-unit.target: Create and upload a Windows Server VHD to Azure

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to upload a virtual hard disk (VHD) with an operating system so you can use it as an image to create virtual machines based on that image.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to upload a virtual hard disk (VHD) with an operating system so you can use it as an image to create virtual machines based on that image.

trans-unit.source: For more details about disks and VHDs in Microsoft Azure, see [About Disks and VHDs for Virtual Machines](virtual-machines-disks-vhds.md).
trans-unit.target: For more details about disks and VHDs in Microsoft Azure, see [About Disks and VHDs for Virtual Machines](virtual-machines-disks-vhds.md).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] When you create a virtual machine based on an image, you can customize the operating system settings as appropriate for the applications you plan to run on the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] When you create a virtual machine based on an image, you can customize the operating system settings as appropriate for the applications you plan to run on the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: This configuration is saved for that virtual machine and doesn't affect the image.
trans-unit.target: This configuration is saved for that virtual machine and doesn't affect the image.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This article assumes you have the following:
trans-unit.target: This article assumes you have the following:

trans-unit.source: **An Azure subscription** - If you don't have one, you can [open an Azure account for free](/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F): You get credits you can use to try out paid Azure services, and even after they're used up you can keep the account and use free Azure services, such as Websites.
trans-unit.target: **An Azure subscription** - If you don't have one, you can [open an Azure account for free](/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F): You get credits you can use to try out paid Azure services, and even after they're used up you can keep the account and use free Azure services, such as Websites.

trans-unit.source: Your credit card will never be charged, unless you explicitly change your settings and ask to be charged.
trans-unit.target: Your credit card will never be charged, unless you explicitly change your settings and ask to be charged.

trans-unit.source: You also can [activate MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F): Your MSDN subscription gives you credits every month that you can use for paid Azure services.
trans-unit.target: You also can [activate MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F): Your MSDN subscription gives you credits every month that you can use for paid Azure services.

trans-unit.source: **Microsoft Azure PowerShell** - You have the Microsoft Azure PowerShell module installed and configured to use your subscription.
trans-unit.target: **Microsoft Azure PowerShell** - You have the Microsoft Azure PowerShell module installed and configured to use your subscription.

trans-unit.source: To download the module, see [Microsoft Azure Downloads](http://azure.microsoft.com/downloads/).
trans-unit.target: To download the module, see [Microsoft Azure Downloads](http://azure.microsoft.com/downloads/).

trans-unit.source: A tutorial to install and configure the module is available [here](../powershell-install-configure.md).
trans-unit.target: A tutorial to install and configure the module is available [here](../powershell-install-configure.md).

trans-unit.source: You'll use the [Add-AzureVHD](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495173.aspx) cmdlet to upload the VHD.
trans-unit.target: You'll use the [Add-AzureVHD](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495173.aspx) cmdlet to upload the VHD.

trans-unit.source: **A supported Windows operating system stored in a .vhd file** - You have installed a supported Windows Server operating system to a virtual hard disk.
trans-unit.target: **A supported Windows operating system stored in a .vhd file** - You have installed a supported Windows Server operating system to a virtual hard disk.

trans-unit.source: Multiple tools exist to create .vhd files.
trans-unit.target: Multiple tools exist to create .vhd files.

trans-unit.source: You can use a virtualization solution such as Hyper-V to create a virtual machine and install the operating system.
trans-unit.target: You can use a virtualization solution such as Hyper-V to create a virtual machine and install the operating system.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see [Install the Hyper-V Role and configure a virtual machine](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh846766.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see [Install the Hyper-V Role and configure a virtual machine](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh846766.aspx).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The VHDX format is not supported in Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The VHDX format is not supported in Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can convert the disk to VHD format using Hyper-V Manager or the [Convert-VHD cmdlet](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh848454.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You can convert the disk to VHD format using Hyper-V Manager or the [Convert-VHD cmdlet](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh848454.aspx).

trans-unit.source: A tutorial on this can be found [here](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/virtual_pc_guy/archive/2012/10/03/using-powershell-to-convert-a-vhd-to-a-vhdx.aspx).
trans-unit.target: A tutorial on this can be found [here](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/virtual_pc_guy/archive/2012/10/03/using-powershell-to-convert-a-vhd-to-a-vhdx.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The following Windows Server versions are supported:
trans-unit.target: The following Windows Server versions are supported:

trans-unit.source: OS
trans-unit.target: OS

trans-unit.source: SKU
trans-unit.target: SKU

trans-unit.source: Service Pack
trans-unit.target: Service Pack

trans-unit.source: Architecture
trans-unit.target: Architecture

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 R2
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 R2

trans-unit.source: All editions
trans-unit.target: All editions

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012

trans-unit.source: All editions
trans-unit.target: All editions

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2008 R2
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2008 R2

trans-unit.source: All editions
trans-unit.target: All editions

trans-unit.source: SP1
trans-unit.target: SP1

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Prepare the image to be uploaded
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Prepare the image to be uploaded

trans-unit.source: Before you can upload the image to Azure, you need to generalize it by using the Sysprep command.
trans-unit.target: Before you can upload the image to Azure, you need to generalize it by using the Sysprep command.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Sysprep, see [How to Use Sysprep: An Introduction](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/bb457073.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Sysprep, see [How to Use Sysprep: An Introduction](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/bb457073.aspx).

trans-unit.source: From the virtual machine that the operating system was installed to, complete the following procedure:
trans-unit.target: From the virtual machine that the operating system was installed to, complete the following procedure:

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the operating system.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the operating system.

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt window as an administrator.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt window as an administrator.

trans-unit.source: Change the directory to **%windir%\system32\sysprep**, and then run `sysprep.exe`.
trans-unit.target: Change the directory to **%windir%\system32\sysprep**, and then run `sysprep.exe`.

trans-unit.source: Open a Command Prompt window
trans-unit.target: Open a Command Prompt window

trans-unit.source: The **System Preparation Tool** dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The **System Preparation Tool** dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: Start Sysprep
trans-unit.target: Start Sysprep

trans-unit.source: In the **System Preparation Tool**, select **Enter System Out of Box Experience (OOBE)** and make sure that **Generalize** is checked.
trans-unit.target: In the **System Preparation Tool**, select **Enter System Out of Box Experience (OOBE)** and make sure that **Generalize** is checked.

trans-unit.source: In **Shutdown Options**, select **Shutdown**.
trans-unit.target: In **Shutdown Options**, select **Shutdown**.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a storage account in Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a storage account in Azure

trans-unit.source: You need a storage account in Azure to upload a .vhd file so it can be used in Azure to create a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: You need a storage account in Azure to upload a .vhd file so it can be used in Azure to create a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Azure portal to create a storage account.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Azure portal to create a storage account.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: On the command bar, click **New**.
trans-unit.target: On the command bar, click **New**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Data Services** > **Storage** > **Quick Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Data Services** > **Storage** > **Quick Create**.

trans-unit.source: Quick create a storage account
trans-unit.target: Quick create a storage account

trans-unit.source: Fill out the fields as follows:
trans-unit.target: Fill out the fields as follows:

trans-unit.source: Under **URL**, type a subdomain name to use in the URL for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Under **URL**, type a subdomain name to use in the URL for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The entry can contain from 3-24 lowercase letters and numbers.
trans-unit.target: The entry can contain from 3-24 lowercase letters and numbers.

trans-unit.source: This name becomes the host name within the URL that is used to address blob, queue, or table resources for the subscription.
trans-unit.target: This name becomes the host name within the URL that is used to address blob, queue, or table resources for the subscription.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **location or affinity group** for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **location or affinity group** for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: An affinity group lets you place your cloud services and storage in the same datacenter.
trans-unit.target: An affinity group lets you place your cloud services and storage in the same datacenter.

trans-unit.source: Decide whether to use **geo-replication** for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Decide whether to use **geo-replication** for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: Geo-replication is turned on by default.
trans-unit.target: Geo-replication is turned on by default.

trans-unit.source: This option replicates your data to a secondary location, at no cost to you, so that your storage fails over to that location if a major failure occurs at the primary location.
trans-unit.target: This option replicates your data to a secondary location, at no cost to you, so that your storage fails over to that location if a major failure occurs at the primary location.

trans-unit.source: The secondary location is assigned automatically, and can't be changed.
trans-unit.target: The secondary location is assigned automatically, and can't be changed.

trans-unit.source: If you need more control over the location of your cloud-based storage due to legal requirements or organizational policy, you can turn off geo-replication.
trans-unit.target: If you need more control over the location of your cloud-based storage due to legal requirements or organizational policy, you can turn off geo-replication.

trans-unit.source: However, be aware that if you later turn on geo-replication, you will be charged a one-time data transfer fee to replicate your existing data to the secondary location.
trans-unit.target: However, be aware that if you later turn on geo-replication, you will be charged a one-time data transfer fee to replicate your existing data to the secondary location.

trans-unit.source: Storage services without geo-replication are offered at a discount.
trans-unit.target: Storage services without geo-replication are offered at a discount.

trans-unit.source: More details on managing geo-replication of Storage accounts can be found here: [Create, manage, or delete a storage account](../storage-create-storage-account/#replication-options).
trans-unit.target: More details on managing geo-replication of Storage accounts can be found here: [Create, manage, or delete a storage account](../storage-create-storage-account/#replication-options).

trans-unit.source: Enter storage account details
trans-unit.target: Enter storage account details

trans-unit.source: Click **Create Storage Account**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create Storage Account**.

trans-unit.source: The account now appears under **Storage**.
trans-unit.target: The account now appears under **Storage**.

trans-unit.source: Storage account successfully created
trans-unit.target: Storage account successfully created

trans-unit.source: Next, create a container for your uploaded VHDs.
trans-unit.target: Next, create a container for your uploaded VHDs.

trans-unit.source: Click the storage account name and then click **Containers**.
trans-unit.target: Click the storage account name and then click **Containers**.

trans-unit.source: Storage account detail
trans-unit.target: Storage account detail

trans-unit.source: Click **Create a Container**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create a Container**.

trans-unit.source: Storage account detail
trans-unit.target: Storage account detail

trans-unit.source: Type a **Name** for your container and select the **Access** policy.
trans-unit.target: Type a **Name** for your container and select the **Access** policy.

trans-unit.source: Container name
trans-unit.target: Container name

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, the container is private and can be accessed only by the account owner.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, the container is private and can be accessed only by the account owner.

trans-unit.source: To allow public read access to the blobs in the container, but not the container properties and metadata, use the **Public Blob** option.
trans-unit.target: To allow public read access to the blobs in the container, but not the container properties and metadata, use the **Public Blob** option.

trans-unit.source: To allow full public read access for the container and blobs, use the **Public Container** option.
trans-unit.target: To allow full public read access for the container and blobs, use the **Public Container** option.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Prepare the connection to Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Prepare the connection to Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Before you can upload a .vhd file, you need to establish a secure connection between your computer and your subscription in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Before you can upload a .vhd file, you need to establish a secure connection between your computer and your subscription in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Microsoft Azure Active Directory method or the certificate method to do this.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Microsoft Azure Active Directory method or the certificate method to do this.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] To get started with Azure PowerShell, see [How to install and configure Microsoft Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] To get started with Azure PowerShell, see [How to install and configure Microsoft Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md).

trans-unit.source: For general information, see [Get Started with Microsoft Azure Cmdlets.](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj554332.aspx)
trans-unit.target: For general information, see [Get Started with Microsoft Azure Cmdlets.](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj554332.aspx)

trans-unit.source: Use the Microsoft Azure AD method
trans-unit.target: Use the Microsoft Azure AD method

trans-unit.source: Open the Azure PowerShell console.
trans-unit.target: Open the Azure PowerShell console.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: This command opens a sign-in window so you can sign with your work or school account.
trans-unit.target: This command opens a sign-in window so you can sign with your work or school account.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Window
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Window

trans-unit.source: Azure authenticates and saves the credential information, and then closes the window.
trans-unit.target: Azure authenticates and saves the credential information, and then closes the window.

trans-unit.source: Use the certificate method
trans-unit.target: Use the certificate method

trans-unit.source: Open the Azure PowerShell console.
trans-unit.target: Open the Azure PowerShell console.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: `Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile`.
trans-unit.target: `Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile`.

trans-unit.source: A browser window opens and prompts you to download a .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: A browser window opens and prompts you to download a .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: It contains information and a certificate for your Microsoft Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: It contains information and a certificate for your Microsoft Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Browser download page
trans-unit.target: Browser download page

trans-unit.source: Save the .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: Save the .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: Where `<PathToFile>` is the full path to the .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: Where `<PathToFile>` is the full path to the .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Upload the .vhd file
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Upload the .vhd file

trans-unit.source: When you upload the .vhd file, you can place the .vhd file anywhere within your blob storage.
trans-unit.target: When you upload the .vhd file, you can place the .vhd file anywhere within your blob storage.

trans-unit.source: In the following command examples, **BlobStorageURL** is the URL for the storage account that you created in Step 2, **YourImagesFolder** is the container within blob storage where you want to store your images.
trans-unit.target: In the following command examples, **BlobStorageURL** is the URL for the storage account that you created in Step 2, **YourImagesFolder** is the container within blob storage where you want to store your images.

trans-unit.source: **VHDName** is the label that appears in the portal to identify the virtual hard disk.
trans-unit.target: **VHDName** is the label that appears in the portal to identify the virtual hard disk.

trans-unit.source: **PathToVHDFile** is the full path and name of the .vhd file.
trans-unit.target: **PathToVHDFile** is the full path and name of the .vhd file.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure PowerShell window you used in the previous step, type:
trans-unit.target: From the Azure PowerShell window you used in the previous step, type:

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Add-AzureVHD
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Add-AzureVHD

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Add-AzureVhd cmdlet, see [Add-AzureVhd](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495173.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Add-AzureVhd cmdlet, see [Add-AzureVhd](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn495173.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Add the Image to Your List of Custom Images
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Add the Image to Your List of Custom Images

trans-unit.source: After you upload the .vhd, you add it as an image to the list of custom images associated with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: After you upload the .vhd, you add it as an image to the list of custom images associated with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: From the portal, under **All Items**, click **Virtual Machines**.
trans-unit.target: From the portal, under **All Items**, click **Virtual Machines**.

trans-unit.source: Under Virtual Machines, click **Images**.
trans-unit.target: Under Virtual Machines, click **Images**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create an Image**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create an Image**.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Add-AzureVHD
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Add-AzureVHD

trans-unit.source: In **Create an image from a VHD**, do the following:
trans-unit.target: In **Create an image from a VHD**, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Specify the **name**.
trans-unit.target: Specify the **name**.

trans-unit.source: Specify the **description**.
trans-unit.target: Specify the **description**.

trans-unit.source: To specify the **URL of your VHD**, click the folder button to open the following window:
trans-unit.target: To specify the **URL of your VHD**, click the folder button to open the following window:

trans-unit.source: Select VHD
trans-unit.target: Select VHD

trans-unit.source: Select the storage account your VHD is in and click **Open**.
trans-unit.target: Select the storage account your VHD is in and click **Open**.

trans-unit.source: This returns you to the **Create an image from a VHD** window.
trans-unit.target: This returns you to the **Create an image from a VHD** window.

trans-unit.source: After you return to the **Create an image from a VHD** window, in the Operating System Family, select your operating system.
trans-unit.target: After you return to the **Create an image from a VHD** window, in the Operating System Family, select your operating system.

trans-unit.source: Check **I have run Sysprep on the virtual machine associated with this VHD** to acknowledge that you generalized the operating system in step 1, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Check **I have run Sysprep on the virtual machine associated with this VHD** to acknowledge that you generalized the operating system in step 1, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Add Image
trans-unit.target: Add Image

trans-unit.source: **OPTIONAL :** You can the **Add-AzureVMImage** cmdlet instead of the portal to add your VHD as an image.
trans-unit.target: **OPTIONAL :** You can the **Add-AzureVMImage** cmdlet instead of the portal to add your VHD as an image.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure PowerShell console, type:
trans-unit.target: In the Azure PowerShell console, type:

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Add-AzureVMImage
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Add-AzureVMImage

trans-unit.source: After you complete the previous steps, the new image is listed when you choose the **Images** tab.
trans-unit.target: After you complete the previous steps, the new image is listed when you choose the **Images** tab.

trans-unit.source: custom image
trans-unit.target: custom image

trans-unit.source: This new image is now available under **My Images** when you create a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This new image is now available under **My Images** when you create a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see [How to create a custom virtual machine running Windows](virtual-machines-windows-create-custom.md).
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see [How to create a custom virtual machine running Windows](virtual-machines-windows-create-custom.md).

trans-unit.source: create VM from custom image
trans-unit.target: create VM from custom image

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] If you get an error when you try to create a VM, with this error message, "The VHD https://XXXXX... has an unsupported virtual size of YYYY bytes.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] If you get an error when you try to create a VM, with this error message, "The VHD https://XXXXX... has an unsupported virtual size of YYYY bytes.

trans-unit.source: The size must be a whole number (in MBs)," it means your VHD is not a whole number of MBs and needs to be a fixed size VHD.
trans-unit.target: The size must be a whole number (in MBs)," it means your VHD is not a whole number of MBs and needs to be a fixed size VHD.

trans-unit.source: Try using the **Add-AzureVMImage** PowerShell cmdlet instead of the portal to add the image (see step 5, above).
trans-unit.target: Try using the **Add-AzureVMImage** PowerShell cmdlet instead of the portal to add the image (see step 5, above).

trans-unit.source: The Azure cmdlets ensure that the VHD meets the Azure requirements.
trans-unit.target: The Azure cmdlets ensure that the VHD meets the Azure requirements.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: After creating a virtual machine, try to create a SQL Server virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: After creating a virtual machine, try to create a SQL Server virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see [Provisioning a SQL Server virtual machine on Microsoft Azure](virtual-machines-provision-sql-server.md).
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see [Provisioning a SQL Server virtual machine on Microsoft Azure](virtual-machines-provision-sql-server.md).
